content.text: Once upon a time, there was a soldier who was marching along the high road—one, two! one, two!
He had his knapsack on his back and his sword at his side, for he had been to the wars and was now returning home.
As he walked, he met an old witch on the road.
She was so ugly that her lower lip hung right down upon her chest.
"Good evening, soldier," said the witch. "What a fine sword you have, and what a big knapsack!
You are a proper soldier!
Now, I will make you rich—richer than you have ever dreamed of—if you will do something for me."  "What must I do?" asked the soldier.
"You must go down into this hollow tree," said the witch, pointing to a great old tree beside the road.
"It is hollow all the way down to the roots, and at the bottom, you will find a large iron chest.
Beside it lies a dog with eyes as big as teacups. But do not be afraid of him.
I will give you my blue-checked apron; you must spread it on the ground, and then take up the dog and set him upon it.
Then you may open the chest and take as much money as you like.
But in the chest, there is also an old tinderbox.
You must bring that to me."  "Why do you want the tinderbox?" asked the soldier.
"That is no business of yours," said the witch.
"Do as I tell you, and you shall have all the money you can carry."  "Very well," said the soldier.
"But how am I to get down into the tree?"  "That is easy enough," said the witch.
"I will tie a rope around your waist, and when you call, I will pull you up again."  So the witch tied the rope around the soldier’s waist, and down he went into the hollow tree.
Sure enough, at the bottom, he found the large iron chest, and beside it sat the dog with eyes as big as teacups.
The soldier was not afraid, for he spread the blue-checked apron on the ground, lifted the dog onto it, and then opened the chest.
Oh, what heaps of money there were!
Gold coins shone in the dim light, and silver pieces sparkled beside them.
The soldier filled his pockets, his knapsack, his cap, and even his boots with gold.
Then he remembered the tinderbox. He took it out and put it in his pocket.
"Now pull me up!" he called to the witch.
The witch began to pull, and soon the soldier stood once more on the high road.
"Give me the tinderbox," said the witch. "Not so fast," said the soldier.
"First, tell me why you want it."  "I will not tell you," said the witch.
"Give it to me at once!"  "No," said the soldier.
"I will keep it until you tell me why you want it."  The witch grew very angry.
"You shall not have a single penny!" she cried, and with that, she cut the rope and left the soldier stranded in the hollow tree.
But the soldier was not afraid.
He struck a light with the tinderbox, and at once, the dog with eyes as big as teacups appeared before him.
"What do you command, master?" asked the dog. "Get me out of here," said the soldier.
In a moment, the dog had carried him up to the top of the tree.
The soldier jumped out and stood once more on the high road.
He struck the tinderbox again, and the same dog appeared. "Bring me some money," said the soldier.
The dog vanished and returned in an instant with a bag full of gold. The soldier was delighted.
He now had more money than he could ever spend.
He went to the nearest town, where he took the finest rooms at the inn, ordered the best food, and lived like a king.
But soon, the soldier began to wonder about the tinderbox.
He struck it once more, and the dog with eyes as big as teacups appeared.
"Is there anything else you can do for me?" asked the soldier. "Anything you wish, master," said the dog.
"Then bring me the loveliest princess in the world," said the soldier.
"I have heard that the king’s daughter is very beautiful, and I should like to see her."  The dog vanished, and in a moment, he returned with the sleeping princess in his arms.
She was so beautiful that the soldier could not help kissing her.
But as he did so, the princess awoke and cried out in alarm.
The dog carried her back to the palace at once.
The next morning, the princess told her parents what had happened. The king and queen were very angry.
They ordered that the soldier should be seized and thrown into prison. But the soldier was not afraid.
He had his tinderbox with him, and when the guards came to take him away, he struck it once, and the dog with eyes as big as teacups appeared.
"Save me!" cried the soldier. The dog seized the guards and threw them out of the window.
Then he carried the soldier away to a safe place. The king was furious.
He ordered his soldiers to find the man who had taken the princess, and to bring him to justice.
But the soldier was too clever for them.
He struck his tinderbox again, and this time, the dog with eyes as big as millstones appeared—a dog even larger and fiercer than the first.
"Bring me the king and queen," said the soldier.
The dog vanished and returned in a moment with the king and queen in his jaws.
They were so frightened that they begged for mercy.
"Spare us," cried the king, "and we will give you the princess in marriage."  The soldier agreed, and so he married the princess and became a prince.
They lived in the palace, and the soldier kept his tinderbox always by his side.
And whenever he struck it, the dogs would appear to do his bidding.
One day, the soldier thought it would be amusing to see the old witch again.
He struck the tinderbox, and the dog with eyes as big as teacups appeared.
"Bring me the witch," he said. The dog vanished and returned with the witch, who was trembling with fear.
"What do you want with me?" she cried. "Tell me why you wanted the tinderbox," said the soldier.
The witch hesitated, but at last, she confessed. "The tinderbox is magic," she said.
"Whoever possesses it can command the three dogs who guard the treasure.
But I could not tell you that before, for then you would have kept it for yourself."  The soldier laughed.
"You were right to be afraid," he said.
"But now that I know the secret, I shall keep the tinderbox forever."  And so he did.
He and the princess lived happily ever after, and the tinderbox brought them all the riches and power they could desire.
